title: The cure for tech addiction is at hand
text:
The idea behind the Palm is a pretty good one: rather than always carrying a huge, powerful phone with you, it gives you the option to carry a tiny, underpowered phone either when you have no pockets (such as at the beach or gym), or when you don’t want to be distracted.

I’ve been carrying a Palm around with me for almost a week, and I have to say it’s been very good at minimising distraction and, by extension, phone usage.

By way of comparison, the screen on this 49mm x 94mm phone is just 27 per cent the size of the screen on a Samsung Galaxy Note 10+. It's exactly as long as the Note’s screen is wide.

The Palm is small enough to fit into the smallest of pockets.

It’s so small, it’s hard to read anything on it, which means I almost never take it out of my pocket unless it’s ringing or I’ve just received a message. (The pocket, incidentally, is the coin pocket on my jeans, meaning I can use the bigger pockets to carry my keys without having to worry about scratching my phone.)

Given that uselessness is rather the point of the Palm, we have to give credit to TCL for pulling out all the stops.

As a result of the screen being so small, the on-screen keyboard is absolutely tiny, especially when you have the Palm in portrait mode, where the buttons are so minuscule you’re basically relying on auto-correct for every other word. It’s a little bigger and easier to type on in landscape mode, but we think you should turn that off in the phone’s settings, to help the Palm achieve optimal uselessness.

The camera, meanwhile, is quite a lot better than we expected but, like the phone itself, it’s not so good that you’ll waste your life away trying to take the perfect selfie.

Being such a small device, its battery life isn’t all that good either, which also helps to minimise usage. I’ve just been scraping through to the end of each day on a single charge, having barely used the phone at all except for those calls and incoming messages.

Ordinarily we’d view that as a huge negative, but given that uselessness is rather the point of the Palm, we have to give credit to TCL for pulling out all the stops.

Advertisement

There is one stop, however, they failed to pull out, and we wish they had. Overseas, there are two versions of the TCL Palm: a standalone version, and a companion version, also known as a useless version and a very useless version, respectively.

Unfortunately, only the useless version has come to Australia.

That’s the one with a SIM rather than an eSIM, meaning you either need to use it as your primary phone (and I’m not sure that many people will have detoxed from smartphones sufficiently to put up with that), or you’ll need to be constantly swapping your SIM card out of your main phone and the Palm, whenever you need the smaller, less distracting device.

The camera is OK, but you're likely to waste less time taking pictures, too.

(The third alternative, to pay for a second phone account just for the Palm, is even less appealing than the first two. Not only will that cost you far more than you’d likely be willing to pay, the phone would also be on a different number from your main phone, rather defeating the point of having a tiny device to carry with you when you don’t want your big device.)

The eSIM version functions very much like an Apple Watch does: for a few extra dollars a month, you connect it to your main phone’s account, allowing you to leave your big phone at home and yet still receive calls and messages when you’re out and about.

Technically, the standalone version is less useless than the companion version, because it doesn’t rely on you also having another phone, but from the point of view of overcoming phone addiction, it’s far less useful than it should be.

It’s such a hassle switching out the SIM on the standalone version of the Palm every time you want to go for a walk, it’s likely the thing will quickly wind up in a drawer somewhere, gathering dust.

But maybe that’s the point. Maybe all our phones should be like that: gathering dust, rather than hoovering up all our time.

TCL PALM PHONE

Likes Could help break a phone addiction

Dislikes Way too expensive. No eSIM variant. Lacks an NFC reader meaning you can’t use it for payments

Price $699
description: The tiny new Palm could help wean you off your phone dependence and ease you back into your life.
